text:
Guider v. Churpeyes


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
LaToya Guider, Respondent,
v.
Churpeyes, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4149
Heard June 15, 2006 â€“ Filed August 14, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Regina H. Lewis and James C. Leventis, Jr., both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Paul W. Owen, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In this action for malicious prosecution and abuse of process, Churpeyes, Inc., (Churchâ€™s) appeals a jury verdict in favor of LaToya Guider.Â  Churchâ€™s alleges the trial court erred in denying its directed verdict motions, admitting testimony from Guiderâ€™s coworker, instructing the jury on punitive damages and breach of trust with fraudulent intent, and failing to deny or reduce actual and punitive damages.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Churpeyes, Inc. owns a chain of restaurants, including a Churchâ€™s Chicken restaurant on Taylor Street in Columbia.Â  Guider worked as general manager of the Taylor Street restaurant in May 2003.Â  
Shortly before closing on the night of May 25, 2003, someone entered the restaurant through an unlocked rear door and robbed it of approximately $860.Â  The shift manager on duty, Selena Harrison, called Guider at home to inform her of the robbery.Â  Guider went to the restaurant, where she found police investigating the incident.Â  She contacted Churchâ€™s area manager, Jimmy Bailey, to inform him of the incident.Â  Bailey told Guider to let police continue their investigation and that he would discuss the matter with her later.Â  
The next day, Bailey met with Guider and told her that leaving the back door of the restaurant unlocked violated company policy, and that the employees who worked on the shift when the robbery occurred would be fired.Â  Guider protested the decision to terminate the employees as unfair, arguing the policy had never been enforced.Â  She also intervened on Harrisonâ€™s behalf with Jerome York, the Vice President of Operations for Churchâ€™s.Â  
On June 4, 2003, Guider received a paycheck from which $430 had been deducted.Â  Guider also received a document entitled â€œDeduction Contractâ€ that Bailey drafted with Yorkâ€™s approval.Â  The document styled itself as a â€œcontractâ€ between Guider and Churchâ€™s in which Guider agreed to have $859 deducted from two paychecks in installments of $430 and $429.Â  According to Bailey and York, the document represented an agreement reached with Guider in which she would reimburse Churchâ€™s for the money taken in the robbery.Â  In return, Churchâ€™s would not terminate Harrison.Â  Guider disputed reaching any such agreement, but nevertheless signed the Deduction Contract.[1]Â  
Guider resigned the following morning.Â  Later that day, she took $1,004 cash from the restaurantâ€™s sales proceeds to deposit in Churchâ€™s bank account.Â  She presented the bank with a deposit slip indicating $1,004 was being deposited.Â  However, she only included $204 in cash with the deposit slip, and intentionally kept the remaining $800.Â  
Immediately after leaving the bank, Guider returned to the restaurant and told Bailey, â€œI need to speak to you about my money.Â  I got my money back.â€Â  She did not specify that she had kept $800 of the money she was supposed to deposit, nor did she offer to return the money.Â  Bailey told Guider he was busy with customers and did not have time to talk to her.Â  Guider gathered her personal items and left.Â  Later that evening, Guider again spoke to Bailey after she called and paged him throughout the day.Â  She told him, â€œI did something that was wrong.Â  I took money out of that $1,004 deposit.â€Â  She added that she would like to meet and discuss returning the $800 to Churchâ€™s and receiving the money it withheld from her paycheck.Â  However, despite Guiderâ€™s repeated attempts to meet with Bailey regarding the money, he either ignored her calls or claimed he was too busy to meet with her.Â  
On June 11, 2003, Bailey asked police to issue an arrest warrant for Guider on breach of trust charges.Â  Six days had passed since Guider informed him that she kept part of the money she was supposed to deposit.Â  The arrest warrant affidavit provided by Bailey alleged Guider admittedly withheld the money she was entrusted to deposit for Churchâ€™s.Â  The affidavit further alleged Guider retained the money â€œfor her own personal use.â€Â  
Guider eventually returned the money to Churchâ€™s by depositing the funds in the companyâ€™s bank account on June 13, 2003.Â  Â She had retained possession of the funds for eight days, during which time Churchâ€™s did not have access to the funds.Â  A municipal court judge signed the arrest warrant on June 19, 2003.Â  Police served Guider with the warrant on June 29, and arrested her on the charges.Â  The charges were dismissed the following day when Churchâ€™s failed to appear at Guiderâ€™s hearing.Â Â  
Thereafter, in October 2003, Guider initiated the present action alleging malicious prosecution, abuse of process, failure to pay wages, false arrest, and violation of Guiderâ€™s civil rights.Â  Guider voluntarily dismissed her civil rights claim before the trial.Â  The trial court dismissed the false arrest claim in pretrial proceedings.Â  
The matter proceeded to jury trial in November 2004.Â  The jury returned a verdict in the amount of $75,000 in actual damages and $100,000 in punitive damages on the malicious prosecution and abuse of process claims.Â  Churchâ€™s made timely post-trial motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV), new trial nisi, and new trial nisi remittitur.Â  The trial court denied the motions.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn ruling on a motion for directed verdict, a court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Swinton Creek Nursery v. Edisto Farm Credit, ACA, 334 S.C. 469, 476, 514 S.E.2d 126, 130 (1999).Â  However, â€œthe appellate court should not ignore facts unfavorable to the opposing party.â€Â Â  Collins v. Bisson Moving & Storage, Inc., 332 S.C. 290, 296, 504 S.E.2d 347, 350 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œRather, it must determine whether a verdict for the opposing party would be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his favor.â€Â  Id.Â  The issue must be submitted to a jury when material evidence tends to establish the issue in the mind of a reasonable juror.Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 149, 485 S.E.2d 903, 908 (1997).Â  â€œHowever, this rule does not authorize submission of speculative, theoretical
and hypothetical views to the jury.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œ[W]hen only one reasonable inference can be deduced from the evidence, the question becomes one of law for the court.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Directed Verdict on Malicious Prosecution
Churchâ€™s argues the trial court erred in denying its directed verdict motion on Guiderâ€™s malicious prosecution claim because she failed to prove Churchâ€™s lacked probable cause to bring a breach of trust charge against her.Â  We agree.
A plaintiff in a malicious prosecution action must show (1) institution or continuation of original judicial proceedings, either civil or criminal; (2) by, or at the insistence of, the defendant; (3) termination of such proceeding in plaintiffâ€™s favor; (4) malice in instituting such proceedings; (5) want of probable cause, and (6) resulting injury or damage.Â  Parrott v. Plowden Motor Co., 246 S.C. 318, 321, 143 S.E.2d 607, 608 (1965).Â  Churpeyes does not dispute its actions satisfy the first two prongs of this test.Â  Instead, it focuses its argument on the prong related to probable cause.[2]
â€œAn essential element of malicious prosecution is the institution of judicial proceedings without probable cause against the plaintiff.â€Â  Kinton v. Mobile Home Indus., Inc., 274 S.C. 179, 181, 262 S.E.2d 727, 728 (1980). â€œProbable cause in this context does not turn upon the plaintiffâ€™s guilt or innocence, but rather
upon whether the facts within the prosecutorâ€™s knowledge would lead a reasonable person to believe the plaintiff was guilty of the crimes charged.â€Â  Id.Â  When determining if probable cause exists, the court must consider the facts from the point of view of the party prosecuting.Â Â 
Eaves v. Broad River Elec. Co-op., Inc., 277 S.C. 475, 478, 289 S.E.2d 414, 416 (1982).Â 
â€œ[T]he question is not what the actual facts were, but what [the prosecuting party] honestly believed them to be.â€ Id.Â  
Looking at the facts from Churchâ€™s point of view for the determination of probable cause, Churchâ€™s filed the breach of trust charges knowing Guider had admittedly retained $800 in company funds with which she had been entrusted on June 5, 2003.Â  Moreover, Guider retained possession of the $800 for a total of eight days before she returned the money to Churchâ€™s.Â  Churchâ€™s filed the charges after Guider told Bailey, â€œI got my money back,â€ â€œI did something that was wrong,â€ and â€œI took money out of that $1,004 deposit.â€Â  Guider had not returned the funds when the charges were filed.Â  
A reasonable party could only conclude Churchâ€™s had probable cause to believe Guider guilty of breach of trust.Â  We find Guider failed to meet her burden of proving Churchâ€™s lacked probable cause to bring breach of trust charges against her.Â  See Parrott, 246 S.C. at 322, 143 S.E.2d at 609 (holding the plaintiff bears the burden of proving the person or entity bringing the charges lacked probable cause to pursue charges against him).Â  Thus, viewing these facts in the light most favorable to Guider, the trial court should have granted Churchâ€™s motion for directed verdict on the malicious prosecution charge as a matter of law.Â  Id. at 323, 143 S.E.2d at 609 (holding although the question of whether probable cause exists is ordinarily a jury question, it may be decided as a matter of law when the evidence yields but one conclusion).
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Directed Verdict on Abuse of Process
Churchâ€™s next argues the trial court erred in denying its directed verdict motion on Guiderâ€™s abuse of process claim.Â  We agree.
â€œThe abuse of process tort provides a remedy for one damaged by anotherâ€™s perversion of a legal procedure for a purpose not intended by the procedure.â€Â  Food Lion, Inc. v. United Food & Commercial Workers Intâ€™l Union, 351 S.C. 65, 69, 567 S.E.2d 251, 253 (Ct. App. 2002). Â â€œThe essential elements of abuse of process are an ulterior purpose and a willful act in the use of the process not proper in the conduct of the proceeding.â€Â  Hainer v. Am. Med. Intâ€™l, Inc., 328 S.C. 128, 136, 429 S.E.2d 103, 107 (1997).Â  â€œAn ulterior purpose exists if the process is used to gain an objective not legitimate in the use of the process.â€Â  First Union Mortgage Corp. v. Thomas, 317 S.C. 63, 74, 451 S.E.2d 907, 914 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œThe improper purpose usually takes the form of coercion to obtain a collateral advantage, not properly involved in the proceeding itself.â€Â  Hainer, 328 S.C. at 136, 492 S.E.2d at 107.Â  Regardless, â€œthere is no liability when the process has been carried to its authorized conclusion, even though with bad intentions.â€Â  Thomas, 317 S.C. at 74-75, 451 S.E.2d at 914.Â  
Viewing the facts in the light most favorable to Guider, we find the record devoid of evidence that Churchâ€™s misused the legal process or operated with an illegitimate purpose.Â  Instead, the evidence shows Churchâ€™s used the legal process with the objective of seeking redress against a former employee who admittedly took and retained company funds.Â  Moreover, when Guider returned the funds, Churchâ€™s stopped pursuing the criminal charges against her.Â  This is clearly a legitimate use, not a perversion, of the legal process.Â  
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court should have granted directed verdicts to Churchâ€™s on Guiderâ€™s claims for malicious prosecution and abuse of process.Â  Â For the forgoing reasons, the verdict in favor of Guider is 
REVERSED.[3]
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ. concur.

[1]Â  Guider challenged Churchâ€™s actions in a complaint she filed with the South Carolina Department of Labor, Licensing and Regulation (LLR) on June 11, 2003.Â  LLRâ€™s Office of Wages and Child Labor eventually found the Deduction Contract invalid and ordered Churchâ€™s to repay Guider the money it withheld from her paycheck.Â  
[2] Churchâ€™s also briefly argues Guider failed to meet her burden of proving the remaining elements of malicious prosecution.Â  The issues of malice and damages were not raised in the directed verdict motion, and thus are not preserved for our review.Â  See Scoggins v. McClellion, 321 S.C. 264, 267, 468 S.E.2d 12, 14 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding issues not raised in directed verdict motion unpreserved for appellate review).Â  
[3] Because we reverse on this issue, we decline to address Churchâ€™s remaining arguments.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (holding an appellate court need not address remaining issues when the resolution of a prior issue is dispositive).
